wiki_catalogs.name: Project Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the TaskMon project overview section focused on introducing the iOS productivity gamification application. Explain its core value proposition of transforming task completion into an engaging creature collection game. Document the application's purpose, target audience, and key differentiators from traditional productivity apps. Describe the main features including task management, creature collection, battle system, and XP progression mechanics. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners understanding gamification concepts and technical highlights for experienced developers. Use terminology consistent with the codebase such as 'TaskMon', 'XP', 'creatures', and 'battle'. Provide practical examples demonstrating the gamified workflow from task completion to creature evolution. Document the pixel art theme, mobile-first design approach, and SwiftUI implementation. Include diagrams where appropriate to illustrate the application architecture and user journey.

wiki_catalogs.name: MVVM Pattern Implementation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for TaskMon's MVVM (Model-View-ViewModel) pattern implementation. Explain how the application separates concerns between Views (SwiftUI components), ViewModels (state management), and Models (data structures). Document the specific implementation of TaskViewModel, CreatureViewModel, and BattleViewModel classes, detailing their responsibilities, state properties, and computed variables. Explain the @StateObject property wrapper usage in TaskMonApp for initializing ViewModels and the .environmentObject() method for cross-view communication. Include concrete examples of how ViewModels expose observable state to Views through @Published properties and how Views react to ViewModel state changes. Document the separation of business logic from UI presentation, showing how ViewModels handle data transformation, validation, and user interactions. Address the benefits of MVVM in SwiftUI applications, including testability, maintainability, and separation of concerns. Provide examples of ViewModel-to-ViewModel communication patterns and state synchronization mechanisms.

wiki_catalogs.name: Task Management System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the Task Management System. Detail the task creation workflow including form validation, category selection, difficulty assignment, and persistence mechanisms. Explain the task completion tracking system with automatic XP awarding, streak counting, and progress visualization. Document the difficulty-based XP reward calculation algorithm and how task categories influence experience point values. Cover the task filtering and organization features including status-based filtering, category sorting, and due date management. Explain the ViewModels responsible for state management, including task CRUD operations, validation logic, and reactive updates. Document the UI components including task list display, individual task cards, add/edit forms, and completion checkboxes. Include implementation details for data persistence using UserDefaults, task lifecycle management, and error handling strategies. Provide code examples demonstrating task creation workflows, completion tracking patterns, and UI binding approaches. Address common use cases such as creating productive daily tasks, tracking completion streaks, and managing task priorities.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Library Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for TaskMon's custom UI component library overview. Explain the design philosophy behind the pixel art theme and how components work together to create a cohesive visual experience. Document the component architecture patterns including shared styling systems, common props, and composition strategies. Describe the relationship between components and their role in the overall application design. Include guidelines for component selection, usage patterns, and integration with SwiftUI's declarative framework. Provide examples of component combinations for building complex interface elements. Document the component lifecycle, state management patterns, and performance considerations. Address accessibility features built into the component library including VoiceOver support and Dynamic Type compatibility.

wiki_catalogs.name: Getting Started
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive getting started documentation for TaskMon development setup. Cover development environment prerequisites including Xcode version requirements, iOS SDK dependencies, and Swift language version. Document step-by-step installation procedures for cloning the repository, configuring Firebase services, and setting up the development environment. Explain Xcode project configuration including build settings, provisioning profiles, and entitlements. Detail Firebase integration options for optional real-time multiplayer features, including GoogleService-Info.plist configuration and service account setup. Provide guidance on running the application on simulators and physical devices. Include troubleshooting common setup issues such as dependency resolution, build errors, and Firebase configuration problems. Document code signing requirements and team provisioning for distribution builds. Address performance considerations for development builds and optimization tips for faster iteration cycles.

wiki_catalogs.name: Reactive Programming with Combine
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for TaskMon's reactive programming implementation using Apple's Combine framework. Explain how Combine publishers and subscribers enable reactive state management across ViewModels. Document the XPManager as the central event coordinator that broadcasts XP events to subscribed components. Detail the use of @Published properties in ViewModels that automatically publish state changes to subscribers. Explain subscription patterns used for cross-component communication, such as task completion triggering creature evolution notifications. Include practical examples of publisher chains, operators like map, filter, and combineLatest for coordinating multiple data streams. Document error handling strategies in reactive pipelines and cancellation patterns for memory management. Address the integration between Combine and SwiftUI's reactive view updates, showing how ViewModels automatically refresh UI when underlying data changes. Provide examples of custom publishers for domain-specific events and how they integrate with the existing XP event system.

wiki_catalogs.name: Creature Collection System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the Creature Collection System. Detail the creature unlocking mechanism triggered by XP milestones, including the 100 XP threshold requirement and creature availability notifications. Explain the evolution system covering the three-stage progression (Stage 1 → Stage 2 → Stage 3) with detailed stat scaling algorithms, base stat modifications, and visual transformation effects. Document the creature generation process including category-based naming conventions, random stat assignment, and unique creature characteristics. Cover the creature management interface including collection display, individual creature details, evolution tracking, and team selection capabilities. Explain the ViewModels responsible for creature state management, evolution logic, and team composition. Document the UI components including creature cards with evolution indicators, detailed creature views with stats display, and evolution animation sequences. Include implementation details for creature persistence, evolution triggers, and stat calculation formulas. Provide code examples demonstrating creature generation patterns, evolution mechanics, and team management workflows. Address common use cases such as unlocking new creatures through XP progression, managing evolving teams for battles, and tracking creature development milestones.

wiki_catalogs.name: PixelButton Component
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the PixelButton component implementation. Document the component's props including title text, color customization, text color options, and action handlers. Explain the interactive behavior with haptic feedback integration using UIImpactFeedbackGenerator. Detail the visual styling including background colors, border effects, shadow properties, and pixel-perfect design elements. Document the button states, hover effects, and touch response animations. Include usage examples showing different button variations for various actions like task creation, navigation, and confirmation dialogs. Explain the component's integration with SwiftUI's Button modifier system and buttonStyle customization. Address accessibility considerations including focus states, keyboard navigation, and screen reader announcements. Provide guidelines for consistent button usage across the application and styling best practices.

wiki_catalogs.name: Architecture Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for TaskMon's iOS application structure. Describe the high-level MVVM (Model-View-ViewModel) design pattern implementation across the entire application. Document component interactions between ViewModels, Services, and Models layers. Explain the reactive programming architecture using Combine framework for state management and cross-component communication. Detail the service layer abstraction using protocol-oriented design for data access and external service integration. Include system context diagrams showing the relationship between TaskMonApp entry point, MainTabView navigation hub, and individual feature ViewModels. Document the XPManager as the central event coordinator facilitating communication between task completion, creature evolution, and battle preparation systems. Address architectural decisions including SwiftUI adoption for declarative UI, UserDefaults for local persistence, and optional Firebase integration. Explain technical constraints, scalability considerations for adding new creature types or battle modes, and maintainability patterns. Document dependency injection patterns, state management strategies, and error handling approaches throughout the architecture.

wiki_catalogs.name: Service Layer Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for TaskMon's service layer design using protocol-oriented programming and dependency injection. Explain how services abstract data access and external functionality behind clean interfaces. Document the protocol-based service architecture that enables easy switching between local and cloud implementations. Detail the XPManager service as the central coordinator for cross-component communication and event broadcasting. Explain the CreatureGenerator service pattern for creating consistent creature instances with proper stat scaling and evolution mechanics. Document the Firebase service protocols and their stub implementations, showing how optional cloud functionality can be integrated without affecting local-only operation. Include examples of dependency injection patterns used in TaskMonApp for initializing services and ViewModels. Address the benefits of service layer abstraction for testing, maintainability, and extensibility. Document service lifecycle management, error handling strategies, and how services coordinate with ViewModels for data persistence and retrieval.

wiki_catalogs.name: Battle System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the Battle System. Detail the battle setup and team management including creature selection limits (up to 3 creatures), team composition strategies, and battle preparation workflows. Explain the turn-based combat mechanics including move selection, damage calculation, type effectiveness modifiers, and win/lose conditions. Document the AI opponent logic covering decision-making algorithms, difficulty levels, and strategic behavior patterns. Cover the battle state management including turn tracking, creature health management, and battle result processing. Explain the multiplayer features including matchmaking coordination, real-time battle synchronization, and opponent management. Detail the ViewModels responsible for battle state management, AI logic coordination, and user interaction handling. Document the UI components including battle arena displays, creature sprites with animations, move selection interfaces, and battle result screens. Include implementation details for the battle engine calculations, type effectiveness matrix, and AI decision trees. Provide code examples demonstrating battle initialization, turn resolution patterns, and multiplayer coordination workflows. Address common use cases such as preparing battle teams, executing strategic moves, and coordinating multiplayer battles.

wiki_catalogs.name: PixelText Component
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the PixelText component covering typography implementation and text rendering. Document the component's props including text content, font size options, color customization, and text alignment settings. Explain the pixel art font rendering system and how text maintains crisp edges at various sizes. Detail the text formatting capabilities including bold, italic, and custom font weight options. Document accessibility features including Dynamic Type support, VoiceOver integration, and text scaling behavior. Include usage examples demonstrating different text styles for headings, body text, labels, and interactive elements. Explain the component's integration with SwiftUI's Text view and font customization options. Address performance considerations for text rendering and memory usage. Provide guidelines for consistent typography usage throughout the application and best practices for text hierarchy and readability.

wiki_catalogs.name: Core Features
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for TaskMon's core feature implementations. Detail the task management system including task creation, completion tracking, difficulty-based XP reward calculation, and persistence strategies. Explain the creature collection system covering creature unlocking thresholds, evolution mechanics across three stages, stat scaling algorithms, and category-based naming conventions. Document the battle system including turn-based combat mechanics, type effectiveness calculations, AI opponent logic, and team management capabilities. Include the XP progression system with milestone thresholds, cross-component event communication, and visual progress indicators. Provide implementation details for each feature's ViewModels, data models, and service integrations. Document user workflows for common scenarios such as completing productive tasks to unlock new creatures, managing evolving teams for battles, and progressing through XP milestones. Address feature interdependencies and data flow between components. Include code examples demonstrating key implementation patterns and configuration options for customization.

wiki_catalogs.name: State Management Patterns
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for TaskMon's state management architecture across multiple layers. Explain how state flows from Models (immutable data structures) through ViewModels (observable state) to Views (UI presentation). Document the hierarchical state management approach where TaskViewModel manages task-related state, CreatureViewModel handles creature collections and evolution, and BattleViewModel coordinates battle scenarios. Detail the use of @Published properties for reactive state updates and how Views automatically re-render when state changes. Explain state synchronization patterns between ViewModels, particularly the linkTaskVM() method that connects creature evolution to task completion events. Document data persistence strategies using UserDefaults for local storage and how state is maintained across app sessions. Address state consistency patterns, preventing race conditions in cross-component state updates, and managing complex state transitions like creature evolution sequences. Include examples of state validation, error recovery, and maintaining UI responsiveness during state-intensive operations.

wiki_catalogs.name: XP & Progression System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the XP & Progression System. Detail the experience point management including XP accumulation from task completions, difficulty-based XP calculations, and XP distribution mechanisms. Explain the milestone threshold system covering the 100 XP unlock threshold for new creatures, 500 XP milestone achievements, and 1000 XP progression markers. Document the cross-component event communication system including XP event broadcasting, listener registration, and state synchronization across ViewModels. Cover the progress tracking mechanisms including XP counters, milestone completion indicators, and visual progress displays. Explain the XPManager's role as the central coordinator for experience point events and milestone handling. Detail the integration with other systems including task completion triggering XP awards, creature evolution requiring XP thresholds, and battle participation influencing XP gains. Include implementation details for XP calculation algorithms, milestone detection logic, and event propagation mechanisms. Provide code examples demonstrating XP awarding workflows, milestone checking patterns, and cross-component communication approaches. Address common use cases such as earning XP through productive task completion, unlocking new creatures at milestones, and tracking overall progression progress.

wiki_catalogs.name: Health Bar Component
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the HPBar component implementation used for displaying creature health and status indicators. Document the component's props including current health value, maximum health, bar color customization, and animation settings. Explain the visual design including gradient effects, border styling, and pixel-perfect health bar rendering. Detail the animation system for health changes including smooth transitions, warning states, and critical health indicators. Document the component's reactive behavior with Combine publishers and real-time health updates. Include usage examples showing different health bar configurations for various UI contexts like creature cards, battle screens, and status displays. Explain the component's integration with SwiftUI's animation system and state binding patterns. Address accessibility features including progress bar semantics, screen reader announcements, and color contrast requirements. Provide guidelines for consistent health bar usage and visual hierarchy in the application.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Models & Persistence
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for TaskMon's core entities and persistence strategies. Detail the TaskItem model including task properties, difficulty levels, completion tracking, and category associations. Document the Creature model covering evolution stages, base stats, type effectiveness, XP requirements, and visual representation. Explain the Battle model structure including turn management, player/team data, move selection, and combat state tracking. Document the Player model for user profile data and progress statistics. Detail the TaskCategory enumeration and CreatureMove data structures supporting the gamified task system. Include field definitions, data types, validation rules, and business constraints for each model. Document the persistence strategy using UserDefaults for local data storage, including serialization approaches and data migration handling. Explain data access patterns, caching strategies for frequently accessed creature data, and performance considerations for large datasets. Specify data lifecycle management, retention policies for completed tasks, and archival rules for creature evolution history. Address data security considerations, privacy requirements for user progress data, and access control patterns. Include sample data structures and JSON representations for each model.

wiki_catalogs.name: Cross-Component Communication
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for TaskMon's cross-component communication mechanisms that enable loose coupling between ViewModels and services. Explain the XPManager's role as the central event coordinator that broadcasts XP events from task completion to trigger creature evolution and battle readiness notifications. Document the observer pattern implementation using Combine publishers and subscribers for decoupled communication. Detail the specific communication flows: task completion → XP awarding → milestone checking → creature evolution → battle team updates. Explain how TaskViewModel notifies CreatureViewModel about XP accumulation and how CreatureViewModel signals BattleViewModel about evolved creatures becoming battle-ready. Include examples of event-driven architecture patterns, showing how components subscribe to relevant events without direct dependencies. Document error propagation patterns, event ordering guarantees, and handling of asynchronous communication. Address performance considerations for frequent state updates and strategies for avoiding notification storms during bulk operations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Creature Sprite View
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the CreatureSpriteView component covering sprite rendering and animation handling. Document the component's props including creature data binding, sprite size options, animation state controls, and category-based artwork selection. Explain the sprite loading system including asset management, lazy loading, and memory optimization techniques. Detail the animation framework for creature sprites including idle animations, attack animations, and evolution transitions. Document the integration with the creature artwork system and how sprites are organized by category and evolution stage. Include usage examples showing different sprite configurations for various UI contexts like creature cards, battle arenas, and collection views. Explain the component's performance optimizations including sprite caching, frame rate management, and GPU acceleration. Address accessibility considerations including creature identification, animation control options, and alternative visual indicators. Provide guidelines for sprite usage consistency and visual design standards across the application.

wiki_catalogs.name: UI Components & Design System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for TaskMon's custom UI component library and design system. Describe the pixel art theme implementation including color palettes, typography choices, and visual consistency across all interface elements. Document the PixelButton component covering button states, animations, touch feedback, and styling variations for different interactive elements. Explain the PixelText component including font rendering, text formatting options, and accessibility considerations for screen readers. Detail the HPBar component implementation for displaying creature health with smooth animations and visual feedback during battles. Document the CreatureSpriteView component covering sprite loading, animation handling, and category-based artwork display. Include usage examples with code snippets demonstrating component integration patterns and prop configurations. Provide guidelines for responsive design adaptation across iPhone device sizes and orientation changes. Document component composition patterns for building complex views from basic components. Address accessibility compliance including VoiceOver support, Dynamic Type scaling, and color contrast requirements. Include style customization options and theming support for future design iterations. Document component state management, event handling patterns, and integration with SwiftUI's reactive state system.

wiki_catalogs.name: Design System Guidelines
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for TaskMon's design system including color palettes, typography scales, spacing systems, and visual consistency guidelines. Document the pixel art theme implementation with color schemes for different creature categories, UI states, and accessibility requirements. Explain the component styling system including shared design tokens, consistent spacing patterns, and responsive layout principles. Detail the accessibility guidelines including color contrast ratios, font sizing standards, and interaction feedback requirements. Document the design system's evolution from initial concept to current implementation, including design decisions and rationale. Include guidelines for maintaining design consistency across new components and feature additions. Provide examples of proper component usage and common design patterns. Address design system maintenance, versioning, and update procedures. Document the relationship between design system guidelines and component implementation standards.

wiki_catalogs.name: Services Layer & External Integrations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for TaskMon's service layer architecture and external integration patterns. Detail the XPManager service as the central event coordinator handling cross-component communication for experience point tracking and milestone notifications. Document the CreatureGenerator service implementing factory patterns for consistent creature creation, evolution mechanics, and move pool generation. Explain the BattleEngine service covering turn-based combat calculations, type effectiveness algorithms, AI decision-making processes, and battle state management. Detail the Firebase service protocols enabling optional real-time multiplayer functionality, including matchmaking coordination, battle synchronization, and cloud data persistence. Document the stub implementations allowing local-only functionality without external dependencies. Include service abstraction patterns using protocol-oriented design for easy swapping between local and cloud implementations. Explain dependency injection strategies for service registration and lifecycle management. Address error handling approaches, retry mechanisms, and graceful degradation when external services are unavailable. Document performance optimization techniques for service operations, caching strategies for frequently accessed data, and memory management for long-running service instances. Include configuration options for service behavior, logging and monitoring integration, and testing strategies for service layer components.

wiki_catalogs.name: Testing Strategy & Quality Assurance
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive testing documentation for TaskMon's quality assurance approach and testing strategies. Detail unit testing approaches for ViewModels covering task management operations, creature evolution logic, and battle state calculations. Document service layer testing including XPManager event coordination, CreatureGenerator factory methods, and BattleEngine combat calculations. Explain SwiftUI view testing strategies for component rendering, user interaction handling, and state change verification. Include testing patterns for reactive programming with Combine publishers, async/await testing for service operations, and mock implementation strategies for external dependencies. Document testing utilities and helper functions for common test scenarios such as task completion workflows, creature evolution sequences, and battle outcomes. Address testing challenges specific to iOS development including simulator limitations, device-specific behaviors, and performance testing approaches. Include continuous integration setup recommendations, automated testing pipelines, and quality gates for code changes. Document debugging strategies for complex state management issues, race conditions in reactive streams, and UI responsiveness problems. Provide guidelines for test data management, test environment configuration, and regression testing approaches for feature additions and bug fixes.

wiki_catalogs.name: Deployment & Distribution
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive deployment and distribution documentation for TaskMon iOS application. Detail Xcode build configuration including project settings, build targets, configuration variants (Debug/Release), and optimization flags for performance and size. Document App Store submission requirements including provisioning profiles, certificate management, app icon requirements, and metadata preparation. Explain Firebase configuration for production deployment including GoogleService-Info.plist management, service account setup for CI/CD, and environment variable handling for different build configurations. Cover performance optimization strategies including code signing verification, app thinning for different device architectures, and bundle size reduction techniques. Document testing procedures for production builds including device testing, beta distribution through TestFlight, and crash reporting integration. Address security considerations for production deployment including keychain access, data encryption, and privacy compliance. Include deployment automation approaches using Fastlane or other CI/CD tools for streamlined release processes. Document rollback strategies, hotfix deployment procedures, and post-release monitoring approaches. Provide troubleshooting guides for common deployment issues such as build failures, provisioning profile errors, and App Store rejection reasons.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>

# Qoder Vibe Code - TaskMon iOS Application

## Project Introduction

### Purpose Statement
TaskMon is an innovative iOS application that gamifies productivity through a Pokémon-inspired creature collection system. Users complete daily tasks to earn experience points (XP) that unlock and evolve digital creatures across five distinct categories: Work, Health, Learning, Creative, and Personal.

### Core Goals and Objectives
- Transform mundane task completion into an engaging, rewarding experience
- Provide a comprehensive creature collection system with evolution mechanics
- Implement both single-player and multiplayer battle functionality
- Maintain offline-first architecture with optional cloud synchronization
- Deliver a polished pixel-art themed user interface

### Target Audience
- Productivity enthusiasts seeking gamification elements
- iOS users interested in creature collection games
- Gamers looking for a unique productivity-focused experience
- Mobile users who enjoy Pokémon-style progression systems

## Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[TaskMonApp] --> B[MainTabView]
    B --> C[TasksView]
    B --> D[CreaturesView]
    B --> E[BattleView]
    
    C --> F[TaskViewModel]
    D --> G[CreatureViewModel]
    E --> H[BattleViewModel]
    
    F --> I[TaskItem Model]
    G --> J[Creature Model]
    H --> K[Battle Model]
    
    F --> L[XPManager]
    G --> L
    L --> M[UserDefaults Storage]
    
    H --> N[FirebaseService]
    N --> O[Stub Implementation]
    N --> P[Real-time Battle]
```

### Design Patterns

The application follows several key architectural patterns:

**MVVM (Model-View-ViewModel)**: Each major feature area uses dedicated ViewModels (`TaskViewModel`, `CreatureViewModel`, `BattleViewModel`) to manage state and business logic.

**Repository Pattern**: Services abstract data access through protocol-based interfaces, enabling easy switching between local and cloud implementations.

**Observer Pattern**: Combine publishers and subscribers manage reactive state updates across the application.

**Factory Pattern**: Creature generation and move pools use factory methods for consistent object creation.

### System Relationships

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[User Input] --> B[ViewModel Layer]
    B --> C[Model Layer]
    C --> D[Service Layer]
    D --> E[Storage Layer]
    
    B --> F[UI Updates]
    F --> A
    
    D --> G[Firebase Backend]
    D --> H[Local Storage]
    
    I[XP Events] --> B
    B --> J[Creature Evolution]
    J --> F
```

## Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- **Application Entry**: `TaskMon/TaskMon/TaskMonApp.swift` - Configures Firebase and initializes global ViewModels
- **Navigation Hub**: `TaskMon/TaskMon/Views/MainTabView.swift` - Primary tab-based navigation system

### Core Modules

#### Data Models
- **Task Management**: `TaskMon/TaskMon/Models/TaskItem.swift` - Task items with difficulty levels and XP rewards
- **Creature System**: `TaskMon/TaskMon/Models/Creature.swift` - Core creature model with evolution mechanics
- **Battle Engine**: `TaskMon/TaskMon/Models/Battle.swift` - Battle state and turn resolution logic

#### Business Logic
- **XP Management**: `TaskMon/TaskMon/Services/XPManager.swift` - Centralized experience point tracking and milestone handling
- **Creature Generation**: `TaskMon/TaskMon/Services/CreatureGenerator.swift` - AI team creation and creature spawning
- **Battle Resolution**: `TaskMon/TaskMon/Services/BattleEngine.swift` - Turn-based combat calculations

#### State Management
- **Task ViewModel**: `TaskMon/TaskMon/ViewModels/TaskViewModel.swift` - Task CRUD operations and XP awarding
- **Creature ViewModel**: `TaskMon/TaskMon/ViewModels/CreatureViewModel.swift` - Creature lifecycle and evolution tracking
- **Battle ViewModel**: `TaskMon/TaskMon/ViewModels/BattleViewModel.swift` - Multiplayer battle coordination and state management

### Configuration Approach
- **Constants**: `TaskMon/TaskMon/Utils/Constants.swift` - Game constants including XP thresholds and UI styling
- **Firebase Integration**: `TaskMon/TaskMon/Services/FirebaseService.swift` - Protocol-based service layer with stub implementations
- **Asset Management**: `TaskMon/TaskMon/Assets.xcassets/` - Comprehensive creature artwork organized by category and evolution stage

### External Dependencies
- **SwiftUI**: Declarative UI framework for modern iOS development
- **Combine**: Reactive programming framework for state management
- **Firebase**: Optional real-time database and authentication services
- **Foundation**: Core iOS frameworks for data persistence and networking

### Integration Points

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant TaskView
    participant TaskVM
    participant XPManager
    participant CreatureVM
    
    User->>TaskView: Complete Task
    TaskView->>TaskVM: completeTask()
    TaskVM->>XPManager: awardXP()
    XPManager->>XPManager: Calculate milestones
    XPManager->>CreatureVM: Send XPEvent
    CreatureVM->>CreatureVM: Handle evolution
    CreatureVM->>TaskView: Update UI
```

## Key Features

### Functionality Overview

#### Task Management System
- **Multi-category Tasks**: Work, Health, Learning, Creative, and Personal task types
- **Difficulty Scaling**: Easy (10 XP), Medium (25 XP), Hard (50 XP) reward structure
- **Persistent Storage**: Local UserDefaults-based persistence for offline functionality
- **Visual Feedback**: Animated XP popup notifications with detailed event logging

#### Creature Collection & Evolution
- **Five Creature Types**: Each category corresponds to unique creature designs and abilities
- **Three Evolution Stages**: Egg → Stage 1 → Stage 2 → Stage 3 progression system
- **Stat Scaling**: Base stats scale with evolution stage and level bonuses
- **Type Effectiveness**: Category-based combat advantages and disadvantages

#### Battle System
- **Local Battles**: AI-powered single-player combat against generated teams
- **Multiplayer Support**: Real-time online battles with matchmaking and turn synchronization
- **Turn-based Combat**: Strategic move selection with damage calculation and status effects
- **Team Management**: Up to 3 creature team composition with switching mechanics

### Implementation Highlights

#### State Management Architecture
- **Reactive Updates**: Combine publishers ensure UI consistency across all ViewModels
- **Cross-component Communication**: XP events trigger automatic creature evolution and UI updates
- **Battle Synchronization**: Real-time state updates with Firebase for multiplayer functionality

#### UI/UX Design System
- **Pixel Art Theme**: Consistent visual styling with custom colors and typography
- **Responsive Layouts**: Adaptive views that work across different iPhone screen sizes
- **Animation Framework**: Smooth transitions and visual feedback for user interactions

### Feature Architecture

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> TaskCreation
    TaskCreation --> TaskCompletion: Complete Task
    TaskCompletion --> XPAward: Award XP
    XPAward --> CreatureUnlock: First Milestone
    XPAward --> Evolution: Stage Threshold
    CreatureUnlock --> Evolution: Level Progression
    Evolution --> BattleReady: Battle Preparation
    BattleReady --> LocalBattle: Start Battle
    BattleReady --> OnlineBattle: Matchmaking
    LocalBattle --> BattleEnd: Victory/Loss
    OnlineBattle --> BattleEnd: Remote Battle
    BattleEnd --> [*]
```

The TaskMon application represents a sophisticated blend of productivity gamification and mobile gaming mechanics, providing users with an engaging way to track daily activities while enjoying a rich creature collection experience.

**Sources:**
- [TaskMonApp.swift](TaskMon/TaskMon/TaskMonApp.swift)
- [MainTabView.swift](TaskMon/TaskMon/Views/MainTabView.swift)
- [Creature.swift](TaskMon/TaskMon/Models/Creature.swift)
- [TaskItem.swift](TaskMon/TaskMon/Models/TaskItem.swift)
- [FirebaseService.swift](TaskMon/TaskMon/Services/FirebaseService.swift)
- [TaskViewModel.swift](TaskMon/TaskMon/ViewModels/TaskViewModel.swift)
- [Constants.swift](TaskMon/TaskMon/Utils/Constants.swift)
- [TasksView.swift](TaskMon/TaskMon/Views/Tasks/TasksView.swift)
- [BattleView.swift](TaskMon/TaskMon/Views/Battle/BattleView.swift)
- [XPManager.swift](TaskMon/TaskMon/Services/XPManager.swift)
- [CreatureViewModel.swift](TaskMon/TaskMon/ViewModels/CreatureViewModel.swift)
- [BattleViewModel.swift](TaskMon/TaskMon/ViewModels/BattleViewModel.swift)
- [TaskCategory.swift](TaskMon/TaskMon/Models/TaskCategory.swift)

</blog>
